**Initialize the Bayesian SVAR Model**

```{r echo=TRUE, results='asis', cache=TRUE}

#########################
### Estimate the model ###
##########################
y<-SBP_m
# init_rbsvar() initializes the model and chooses efficient initial values for
# when sampling from the posterior distribution of the parameters in the next step.
svar_mp <- init_rbsvar(y = y,
                          lags = 12,
                          constant = T,
                          type = "svar",
                          shrinkage = Inf
)

```

```{r echo=TRUE, results='asis', cache=TRUE}

# est_rbsvar() estimates the model by drawing n(=2) chains from the posterior
# distribution of the parameters, starting from values provided by init_rbsvar().
# Chains are of length K*N (=10*N) and they are thinned by a factor of K(=10),
# thus the final sample consists of n*N (=2*N) non-independent draws. The chains
# are drawn with differential evolution Monte Carlo algorithm.
#
# Even though the algorithm is parallelized, this might take some time.
N <- 1000000 # 100000
burn <- 900000 # OK until 600000
output_mp<- est_rbsvar(svar_mp,
                           N = N,
                           n = 2,
                           K = 10,
                           parallel_chains = TRUE,
                           parallel_likelihood = TRUE)


```

# CH 4 Empirical analysis

The empirical analysis investigates the effects of monetary policy on macroeconomics variable . This will be done by identifying the monetary policy shock in the SVAR model described in detail in section 3. The data covers the period 1974:M1-2024:M9 . The results of this studies will be discussed in the next subsection to give an understanding about the dynamics of the impulse reponses and baseline to which to **compare the results of the model estimated in this thesis.** The impulse reponse functions of the benchmark model will be studied . Finally, the model will be estimated with time periods by utilizing data from 1974 to 2024. The idea is to study how the effects of the monetary policy effect the macroeconomics variable might have changed over the years as the tools for conducting monetary policy have changed and severe economical shocks. In this paper, we are interested in the interaction of monetary policy shocks and in shocks leading to convergence or divergence.. A positive long-run response would imply that the central bank applies monetary policies to stabilize the currency . Expansionary monetary policies reduce divergence in the short run. A negative short-run response would imply that unconventional monetary policy helps to mitigate economic differences across countries by providing liquidity and easing financial conditions, though these effects may not be sustained over the longer term. To test whether there is a single shock among the n statistically identified ones that satisfies the sign restrictions we consider, we employ the Bayesian procedure of Anttonen et al. (2024) discussed in Section 3.\
\
First step in estimating VAR(ð‘) model is to conclude the order of ð‘, namely the lag length of the model. Order of VAR(ð‘) can be defined based on various information criteria methods. In this study, Akaikeâ€™s, Bayesian, and Hannah-Quinnâ€™s information criteria are applied (for more detailed information, see, e.g., Akaike (1973), Schwarz (1978), and Hannan and Quinn (1979)). With correctly specified order of VAR(ð‘), one can find the best trade-off between the accuracy and parsimony of the model.

In this study, the appropriate lag length for the VAR model is determined based on Akaikeâ€™s information criteria (AIC). Although other information criteria suggest a lag length of 1, the AIC suggests a lag length of 2, resulting in a VAR(2) model. Despite the possibility of a higher lag length for monthly time series, this study relies on the results of AIC. VAR(12) model was run in a test manner, and no significant deviation from the results of VAR(2) was detected. After conduction of serial autocorrelation tests, no significant autocorrelation in the residuals was observed.\

The SVAR model is estimated with Bayesian methods, assuming non-Gaussian errors. The parameters of posterior distributions were simulated using a Hamiltonian MCMC based algorithm . Two MCMC chains were employed in the simulation, and both demonstrated good convergence properties as indicated by their respective trace plots, which are included in this thesis. No sudden jumps or divergences were observed in the MCMC chains. Smooth trace plots partly reflect chain convergence. However, convergence was further assessed through convergence diagnostics, ensuring that all values satisfied the convergence criteria of ð‘…Ì‚ \< 1.10. in this thesis sample two chains (N = 2) from the posterior distribution of the parameters, each consisting of 100000 draws. After discarding all but the last 18,000 draws from each chain, the chains have clearly converged according to the RË† convergence statistic

# Estimation and identification

# Convergence Diagnostic

We use the R-package of Anttonen et al. (2024) which is available via GitHub (https: //github.com/jetroant/rbsvar). The estimation of the model in Section 3 required 20 million posterior evaluations (two chains and ten inner iterations per step) with 492 parameters. The number of burn-in draws (the draws to be discarded before accepting draws from the chain as the posterior sample) were chosen so that for the final chains of sufficient length (in our case 18,000 posterior draws with 10 inner iterations totaling at 1 million draws per chain), the RË† convergence statistic of Gelman et al. (2013) did not exceed the threshold of 1.10 for any of the 492 parameters in the model. Figure 4A.1a depicts the distribution of the marginal RË† convergence statistics. Evidently, with respect to most of the parameters in the model, the statistic is very close to unity. Figure 4A.1b suggests, even far fewer draws would have provided us with acceptable performance. We checked our results for sensitivit length of the burn-in sample and found the results essentially identical whether 820,00 burn-in samples were drawn\

```{r echo=TRUE, results='asis', cache=TRUE}

# convergence() computes the R_hat convergence statistic of Gelman et al. (2013)
# with respect to every parameter in the model and plots the results.
# Values below the threshold of 1.1 can be interpreted as implying convergence of the chains.
convergence_mp <- convergence(output_mp, burn=burn)
# Save the posterior sample (Or load by commenting/uncommenting the below lines)
saveRDS(output_mp, "output_mp.rds")
output_mp <- readRDS("output_mp.rds")

```

### Tail exponent marginal posteriors \### (Highly dependent on convergence)

The validity of the assumption of non-normal error terms was supported by the simulation of the posterior distributions of the model's free parameters. The estimation is based on the assumption about the non-Gaussianity of the error terms. To asses the validity of this assumption, the posterior distributions of the parameters defining the distribution of the error terms were analyzed and are shown in Figure 4.2A The median of the estimated distributions are shown in Table 4.1.

The estimated values of ð‘ð‘– approximating 2, ð‘žð‘– much greater than zero, and Lambda ðœ†ð‘– being near zero, imply a Gaussian or near Gaussian distribution. In particular, it needs to be checked if there is a high probability for more than one of the shocks to be Gaussian. A Gaussian or nearly Gaussian distribution would result from parameters Î»i â‰ˆ 0, p â‰ˆ 2 and qi \>\> 0. In our case, the marginal densities near the Gaussian regions are not especially high, supporting the assumption of non-Gaussianity. As noted by Anttonen et al. (2024), the Gaussianity would also be seen as wide posterior marginal densities and hence wide credible intervals for the impulse response functions. If reasonable impulse response functions are obtained, one can already assume that the errors are non-Gaussian.\

The results provide a detailed understanding of the skewness, scale, and tail behavior of the shocks, emphasizing their non-Gaussian nature. Skewness (Î»i\lambda\_iÎ»iâ€‹) represents the asymmetry in the shocks, with **Shocks 1, 4, 5, and 6** exhibiting moderate skewness, while **Shock 6** has the highest skewness overall. In contrast, **Shock 3** displays near-zero skewness, indicating a symmetric distribution. The scale parameter (logâ¡p\log\_plogpâ€‹) reflects the variability of the shocks. **Shock 3** stands out with the largest scale (0.9097), indicating greater dispersion, whereas **Shocks 2, 4, and 5** have smaller scales, signifying lower variability. Tail behavior (logâ¡q\log\_qlogqâ€‹) highlights the extremity of the shocks. **Shocks 2 and 4** demonstrate very heavy tails, suggesting a higher likelihood of extreme values, while **Shock 3** has extremely light tails, indicating very few extremes. **Shock 6**, despite its high skewness, shows thin tails (logâ¡q\<0\log\_q \< 0logqâ€‹\<0), limiting the potential for extreme events.

The analysis supports the assumption of non-Gaussian error terms by demonstrating that the shocks deviate significantly from Gaussian behavior. For a Gaussian or near-Gaussian distribution, parameters would converge to Î»iâ‰ˆ0\lambda\_i \approx 0Î»iâ€‹â‰ˆ0, logâ¡pâ‰ˆ2\log\_p \approx 2logpâ€‹â‰ˆ2, and logâ¡q\>\>0\log\_q \>\> 0logqâ€‹\>\>0. However, the results show no strong concentration near Gaussian regions, reinforcing the conclusions of the *"Statistically Identified Structural VAR Model"* paper. Specifically, deviations in skewness and tail behavior highlight the flexibility of the skewed generalized t-distribution (SGT) in capturing real-world economic shocks. **Shocks 2 and 4** are particularly prone to extremes due to their heavy tails, while **Shock 6**, despite its pronounced skewness, remains less extreme due to its thin tails. In contrast, **Shock 3** behaves symmetrically and has minimal extremes, suggesting stability. Overall, this analysis underscores the importance of accounting for non-Gaussian characteristics in economic shocks, enhancing the robustness and realism of SVAR models.

### 4 Impulse response functions

The effects of the monetary policy shock is analyzed through impulse response functions (IRFs), shown in Figure 4.1. The IRFs represent responses of the model variables to one standard deviation positive shocks. The shaded areas indicate 68% and 90% percentiles of the IRFs calculated using draws from the posterior distributions of the model parameters. the impulse responses of the identified monetary policy shock, which along with their 68% and 90% posterior intervals are depicted in Figure 4.1

\
As discussed in subsection 3.1, the impulse response function serves as a method for assessing the reaction of variables to a policy shock. The present section offers an in-depth examination of the impulse responses of six variables deployed in this study pertaining to an MP shock. Given that all other assumptions have been affirmed, the impulse response functions are capable of furnishing reasonably credible findings concerning the influence of monetary policy measures on the maroecomonics case of pakistan . The fundamental concept underlying the impulse response function analysis is to identify a shock or set of shocks that conform to the priorly specified identification criteria of zero and sign restrictions (see subsection 3.2).Before proceeding with the shock analysis, it is imperative to establish the validity of the assigned zero and sign restrictions. This entails verifying whether the data is consistent with the assumed restrictions. Since the model does not provide any statistical identification for economic means, additional assumptions on the impulse responses must be made. If the mode is constructed appropriately, the data is reasonable, and theoretical support exists for the zero and sign restrictions assumed, a shock corresponding to the identified setup should exist. In the absence of such a pattern, one can conclude that the data does not support the assumed zero and sign restrictions .In order to give economic meaning to a shock, one has to make additional assumptions about the dynamics of the shock to be named. Here, the sign restrcitions used by Boeckx et al. (2017) are used for labelling. If some of the statistically identified shocks is satisfying the sign restrictions, it can be considered as an monetary policy shock. If no such shock is found, then it is concluded that the data does not lend support for the sign restrictions. In other words, there is no fundamental structural shock that would behave as required by the sign restrictions.

The impulse response functions (IRFs) of the SVAR model for Pakistan reveal dynamic relationships among key macroeconomic variables, responding to six identified shocks: inflation (INF shocks 1), real effective exchange rate (REER shocks 2), broad money (M2 shocks 3), reserve money (RM shocks 4), external reserves (TR shocks 5), and the SBP policy rate (SBPR shocks 6).

### **Interpretation of Responses by Shock** Figure 4.1

#### **Shock 1: Inflation (INF)**

A shock to inflation results in a significant and immediate increase in the Consumer Price Index (CPI), which stabilizes over 20â€“30 periods, indicating a transitory effect. The inflation shock causes the real effective exchange rate (REER) to depreciate, likely due to reduced competitiveness stemming from higher domestic prices. Both broad money (M2) and reserve money (RM) contract slightly in response, reflecting a potential tightening of monetary conditions. Meanwhile, the SBP policy rate (SBPR) rises sharply, consistent with the central bankâ€™s inflation-targeting mandate to counteract price instability.

#### **Shock 2: Exchange Rate (REER)**

A shock to the REER causes immediate depreciation, followed by a gradual reversal. This depreciation passes through to domestic prices, leading to a rise in inflation, highlighting the sensitivity of the CPI to exchange rate movements. Monetary aggregates (M2 and RM) show mild reactions, indicating limited but noticeable adjustments in monetary policy. The policy rate (SBPR) increases in response to manage inflationary pressures stemming from the exchange rate depreciation.

#### **Shock 3: Broad Money (M2)**

An M2 shock leads to a temporary rise in the money supply, which gradually stabilizes. Inflation increases following the rise in money supply, reflecting the classical relationship between monetary expansion and price levels. The REER depreciates mildly, suggesting that inflationary pressures also affect exchange rate stability. The SBP responds with a higher policy rate, aiming to control inflation and restore monetary equilibrium.

#### **Shock 4: Reserve Money (RM)**

A shock to RM results in an immediate increase in reserve money, which normalizes over time. Similar to the M2 shock, inflation rises modestly, and broad money expands slightly. The REER experiences mild depreciation, signaling inflationary effects on external competitiveness. The SBP raises the policy rate to curb inflation, showing a proactive monetary policy stance.

#### **Shock 5: Reserves (TR)**

An external reserves shock positively impacts reserves immediately, stabilizing quickly. Inflation decreases slightly, reflecting the stabilizing role of reserves in dampening inflationary pressures. The REER appreciates marginally, indicating enhanced external stability and credibility. The policy rate decreases slightly, signaling reduced inflationary pressures and easing of monetary policy in response to improved external buffers.

#### **Shock 6: SBP Policy Rate (SBPR)**

A shock to the SBP policy rate demonstrates its effectiveness in managing inflation. The CPI decreases following the rate hike, validating the use of interest rate tools for price stabilization. The REER appreciates, consistent with tighter monetary policy attracting foreign capital and strengthening the exchange rate. Both M2 and RM contract, reflecting the tightening of monetary conditions and reduced money supply growth.

### Narrative signs - shock probabilities

```{r, echo=TRUE, results='asis', cache=TRUE}
#############################################
### Narrative signs - shock probabilities ###
#############################################

narrative_sign_probs <- function(decomp_obj,
                                 start_date,
                                 freq,
                                 dates,
                                 signs) {
  
  N <- dim(decomp_obj$E)[1]
  m <- dim(decomp_obj$E)[6]
  probs <- matrix(NA, nrow = length(dates), ncol = m)
  total_probs <- rep(NA, m)
  for(i in 1:m) {
    for(j in 1:length(dates)) {
      picked <- rbsvar:::shock_decomp_pick(decomp_obj, show_date = dates[[j]], start_date = start_date, freq = freq)
      if(signs[j] == 1) agree_dummy <- picked$E[,i] > 0
      if(signs[j] == -1) agree_dummy <- picked$E[,i] < 0
      if(j == 1) {
        agree_dummies <- agree_dummy
      } else {
        agree_dummies <- cbind(agree_dummies, agree_dummy)
      }
    }
    probs[,i] <- apply(agree_dummies, 2, mean)
    total_probs[i] <- mean(apply(agree_dummies, 1, function(x) ifelse(sum(x) == length(x), TRUE, FALSE)))
  }
  ret <- rbind(probs, total_probs)
  rownames(ret) <- c(1:length(dates), "Total")
  ret
}
```

### Shock volatility figure

THE Figure 4.8 illustrates the time series of monetary policy shocks, showcasing fluctuations in shock volatility from the 1960s to recent years. These fluctuations suggest periods of varying policy activity and economic conditions, with notable episodes of heightened volatility. The shocks remain mostly centered around zero, but there are periods of significant deviations, indicating transient changes in monetary policy stance or external factors influencing the economy.

The results highlight that while monetary policy shocks appear stable during some periods, episodes of increased volatility (e.g., during global financial crises or significant policy shifts) are evident. This behavior suggests potential heteroskedasticity, where certain periods exhibit higher volatility than others. For instance, the late 1970s and early 1980s may correspond to the **Volcker period in the 1980s**,, known for aggressive monetary tightening, resulting in greater deviations from the mean. Similarly, the recent spikes in the 2020s could be associated with economic uncertainties and policy responses to the COVID-19 pandemic.

These findings also support the idea that monetary policy shocks do not follow a purely Gaussian distribution. Instead, they display periods of clustering volatility, which aligns with economic theories suggesting that external shocks or significant policy adjustments create waves of instability.

The analysis underscores the importance of incorporating non-Gaussian and heteroskedastic shock distributions in monetary policy research. This approach allows for a better understanding of the variability and persistence of shocks over time, especially during historically volatile periods. By accounting for these dynamics, policymakers and researchers can improve the accuracy and applicability of their models to real-world scenarios.The graph provides a clear view of the temporal dynamics of monetary policy shocks, emphasizing periods of heightened volatility associated with major economic events. Understanding these fluctuations is crucial for modeling monetary policy's impact on macroeconomic stability and improving the identification of shocks in econometric frameworks.

### SVAR Model

### Introduction to the Results of the SVAR Model

This study employs a **Structural Vector Autoregressive (SVAR) model** to analyze the dynamic interrelationships among key macroeconomic variables in Pakistan, including the **SBP Policy Rate (SBPR)**, **Inflation (INF)**, **Real Effective Exchange Rate (REER)**, **Broad Money (log(M2))**, **Reserve Money (log(RM))**, and **Gold and Foreign Exchange Reserves (log(TR))**. By decomposing shocks into structural components and identifying their effects through impulse response functions (IRFs) and forecast error variance decomposition (FEVD), this analysis provides a detailed understanding of the transmission mechanisms and the relative contributions of various shocks across time horizons.

The SVAR model is estimated to capture both the short-term and medium-to-long-term interactions, allowing us to identify the responses of these macroeconomic variables to structural shocks originating from inflation, monetary aggregates, exchange rate dynamics, and policy actions. These results are particularly relevant in the context of Pakistanâ€™s economy, where external vulnerabilities, inflationary pressures, and exchange rate dynamics significantly influence monetary policy outcomes.

The analysis is divided into two parts:

1.  **Impulse Response Functions (IRFs)**: These measure the response of one variable to a one-standard-deviation shock in another variable, providing insights into the direction, magnitude, and persistence of these responses.

2.  **Forecast Error Variance Decomposition (FEVD)**: This evaluates the proportion of the forecast error variance of each variable attributable to its own shocks and shocks from other variables at different time horizons (lags).

The results reveal several important dynamics:

-   The **SBP Policy Rate (SBPR)** plays a significant role in influencing inflation and exchange rate dynamics, although its long-term effectiveness diminishes, highlighting potential structural constraints in the monetary transmission mechanism.

-   **Inflation (INF)** demonstrates high persistence, largely driven by its own shocks, suggesting that inflationary pressures in Pakistan are deeply entrenched and self-reinforcing.

-   The **Real Effective Exchange Rate (REER)** is highly sensitive to monetary policy and inflationary shocks, reflecting its critical role in balancing external competitiveness and macroeconomic stability.

-   Monetary aggregates, including **Broad Money (M2)** and **Reserve Money (RM)**, exhibit weaker immediate impacts on key macroeconomic variables but interact strongly with each other, indicating the foundational role of monetary policy in influencing liquidity conditions.

-   **Gold and Foreign Exchange Reserves (TR)** appear to be largely exogenous, with limited feedback effects from other domestic variables, highlighting their dependence on external factors such as trade and capital flows.

    # Interpreting the Results of the SVAR Model for Pakistan's Macroeconomic Dynamics:

    The results of the **Structural Vector Autoregressive (SVAR) model** reveal key insights into the dynamic relationships among six major macroeconomic variables in Pakistan: the **SBP Policy Rate (SBPR)**, **Inflation (INF)**, **Real Effective Exchange Rate (REER)**, **Broad Money (log(M2))**, **Reserve Money (log(RM))**, and **Gold and Foreign Exchange Reserves (log(TR))**. These relationships are analyzed using **Impulse Response Functions (IRFs)** and **Forecast Error Variance Decomposition (FEVD)**, which help to identify the responses of variables to structural shocks and the contribution of these shocks to the forecast error variance of each variable across different time horizons.

    The IRF analysis demonstrates that the **SBP Policy Rate (SBPR)** significantly influences both inflation (INF) and the exchange rate (REER), consistent with the traditional monetary transmission mechanism. In particular, a rise in SBPR reduces inflation in the short term (a disinflationary effect), but the impact diminishes over time, reflecting structural constraints in the economy. SBPR also leads to an appreciation of the REER, potentially due to capital inflows or reduced demand for foreign currency. On the other hand, **inflation (INF)** shows high persistence, with its own shocks driving most of its variance, highlighting the entrenched and self-reinforcing nature of inflationary pressures in Pakistan. Inflation shocks also cause REER depreciation, implying a loss of external competitiveness, while monetary aggregates like M2 and RM respond with notable lags to inflation shocks.

    The FEVD results further quantify the contributions of these shocks to the forecast error variance of each variable. For instance, over 95% of the variance in SBPR is explained by its own shocks in the short term, but this reduces to 86% in the long term, with growing contributions from inflation and external reserves (TR). Similarly, inflation remains largely driven by its own shocks (85â€“98%), suggesting that external variables like SBPR or REER play only a modest role in controlling inflation. REER is primarily driven by its own shocks (79â€“88%), but inflation and SBPR contribute significantly in the medium to long term. Meanwhile, monetary aggregates (M2 and RM) and TR are largely self-driven, with limited contributions from other variables.

    These findings have important implications for policy. The results highlight that **monetary policy alone may not be sufficient to address inflation**, given its high persistence and structural drivers. Policymakers must also focus on **structural reforms**, such as reducing supply-side bottlenecks and improving productivity, to achieve sustained inflation control. Additionally, **exchange rate stability** is critical to managing the pass-through effects of REER on inflation and ensuring external competitiveness. The limited short-term influence of monetary aggregates (M2 and RM) on key macroeconomic variables suggests that improving the efficiency of the **monetary transmission mechanism** is crucial. This could involve enhancing financial sector depth, reducing fiscal dominance, and strengthening the linkages between monetary policy instruments and economic outcomes.

    Overall, the SVAR results provide a nuanced understanding of Pakistanâ€™s macroeconomic dynamics, underscoring the need for a combination of effective monetary policy, structural reforms, and external sector management to achieve economic stability.
